elements.text: PART ONE
1. EXT. JUNGLE. NIGHT
SOUNDS — ANIMALS, CICADAS, CHATTERING BIRDS. REEF & DARL
THROUGH UNDERGROWTH. THEY TALK IN HUSHED TONES, NOT WANTING TO BE OVERHEARD.
(FX: PARTING UNDERGROWTH) There it is, Darl — the temple.
Are you sure about this, Reef?
We can’t turn back now.
This is all wrong. You’re a Service Assistant!
And that’s why I’ve got to do something! We’ve been good citizens. We’ve done everything the Priestess has told us.
(UNSURE) I know, but...
We’re told that if we live a good life, obey the commandments, then we will be rewarded. Well, we’ve done all that, for generations, and still we live like animals in the dirt.
It’s the same for everyone.
Then everyone deserves better! (MORE GENTLY:) Think of your father, wasting away. He won’t survive the winter unless we all get more food.
I know.
The temple steps look to be clear. Now’s our chance. Come on.
AS THEY PUSH FORWARD.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 3
2. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
‘HOVER’ MODE. THE DOCTOR NOISILY RUMMAGING THROUGH BOXES.
No... (THROWS BOX ASIDE, DELVES INSIDE ANOTHER) No... (THROWS BOX ASIDE, DELVES INSIDE ANOTHER) No...
(ENTERING) Doctor, what on Earth are you doing with all these boxes?
Mel! There you are!
The control room looks like a bomb’s hit it.

Yes, well — the problem with the TARDIS having an almost limitless amount of space is that there’s an almost limitless number of things one can keep, and an almost limitless number of places one can put them.
So what is it you’re looking for, exactly?
It’s a surprise. (MORE RUMMAGING) Ah!
Success?
(FX: SHAKING BAG OF MARBLES) No, but I’ve found my marbles. I thought I’d lost them.
(LAUGHING) Why am I not surprised?!
RUMMAGING.
Ah-ha! Here they are! I knew they were in here somewhere! (GETTING UP, HOLDING OUT TICKETS) Take them, take them.
(TAKING TICKETS) Tickets? (READING) ‘The Tragedy of the Cyborgs’ by the Megrootii (meg-rooty) Pla-
CROSSES TO CONSOLE, PRESSES CONTROLS THROUGH:
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 4
(CORRECTING HER) Megrootii (meg-rooty-EYE).
Megrootii (meg-rooty-EYE) Planetary Opera.
At the grand concert hall on Megrootii Prime, no less!
What’s so special about the Megrootii Planetary Opera?
The Megrootii have three heads each, so every member of the company can harmonise with themselves.
It sounds extraordinary.
It is. (FX: TARDIS ENGINES GRINDING) Even if all those extra heads make it hard to get a clear view from the stalls...
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 5
3. INT. TEMPLE
LARGE, CREAKY SWING DOOR PUSHED OPEN FROM OUTSIDE.
VOICES, AS BEFORE.
It’s alright. (STEPPING INTO LARGE SPACE) Come on, there’s no- one here.
FOLLOWS — DOOR SWINGS SHUT BEHIND.
The Temple isn’t guarded?
Why bother? Who’s going to be stupid enough to defy the High Priestess and try to contact the Warehouse?
Us, apparently.
(STEPPING UP TO AN ALTAR-LIKE DESK) Look, here it is. I told you. (SLIGHTLY IN AWE:) The Terminal.
So it’s really true. I never really believed...
A direct line to God.
OPERATES KEYBOARD — CLATTERING.
(FLICKERY, FAINT) Please place your order.
You see, Darl. Anything we want, anything. We just have to ask for at!
(APPROACHING FROM OFF) What a shame you won’t live to see it delivered.
Oh no...
(CLAPS HANDS) Assistants! — Seize them!
2 x ACOLYTES RUSH FORWARD FROM OFF TO SEIZE REEF AND DARL.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 6
(STRUGGLING) Lydek, High Priestess, please, I can explain...
Explain? There is nothing to explain. (TO THE ACOLYTES) Bind her.
(STRUGGLING) Leave her alone, it’s me you want!
Reef. You have betrayed your position in Customer Service. (TO ONE OF THE OTHER ACOLYTES) Remove his card.
THERE IS A SCUFFLE AS THE CARD IS TAKEN FROM HIM
You were a loyalty card holder, Reef. Only the chosen few were issued with these. You swore upon the Catalogue to uphold our
laws. This betrayal cannot go unpunished. Both of you will pay the penalty.
But you can’t...!
Lydek, please! Darl only went along with it for the sake of her family. For her father!

Then her family will have to survive without her. The law is clear. The Terminal may not be accessed by any but the appointed servant of the Warehouse. I alone can ask for Delivery. The punishment for what you have done is death. Take them away.
REEF AND DARL ARE DRAGGED AWAY.
No! High Priestess, forgive me!
Lydek, for the love of... (A HAND IS PLACED OVER HIS MOUTH)
(TO HERSELF) Such a waste. Such... (TAPPING A KEY ON THE KEYBOARD) a.. (ANOTHER KEY) waste. (A FINAL KEY TAP.)
Transaction cancelled. Awaiting connection... Awaiting connection...
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 7
4. INT. WAREHOUSE — BAY E
MATERIALISES IN A CAVERNOUS SPACE. RATTLE OF DOOR CATCH AS DOCTOR AND MEL STEP OUT.
If this is the Grand Concert Hall of the Megrootii then it’s looking a little past its prime.
It would appear that we’ve overshot slightly.
So where are we?
I’m not entirely sure...
It looks like a warehouse of some kind. A very big warehouse. There must be miles of shelves!
Miles of shelves and millions of boxes. (FX: CLOSES TARDIS DOOR) Ah well, since we’re here, we might as well have a little look round. (HEADING OFF A FEW PACES)
(NOT MOVING FROM HER SPOT) Might we. From the looks of it, no one’s been here for years. It’s dark, dusty and (SNIFFS) something smells decidedly mouldy.
Just a quick wander down a few of the aisles, Mel? I’m intrigued.
Oh, alright. (WALKING TO JOIN THE DOCTOR) Just as long as we don’t miss that concert! You’ve got me all excited about it now!
THE TWO OF THEM SET OFF, FOOTSTEPS ECHOING. WE STAY WHERE WE ARE, THEIR VOICES RECEDING.
A quick recce, nothing more. I promise.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 8
5. INT. SUPERVISOR’S OFFICE [CONTINUOUS]
THE DOCTOR AND MEL’S FOOTSTEPS CONTINUE OVER CCTV — THEY’RE
WATCHED ON A MONITOR.
‘BLUP’ OF A WATERCOOLER.
Interesting... we seem to have intruders in the Warehouse... (SLURPS WATER) Where did you spring from, I wonder?
(CCTV) What are they keeping here? What’s it all for?
(CCTV) According to the label, these shelves are stacked with... (READING) biscuits.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 9
6. INT. WAREHOUSE SHELVES [CONTINUOUS]
Who on earth would want this many biscuits? I can’t even see the end of the aisle.
(CROSSING TO WALL) Ah! This might shed some light on things.
(FOLLOWING) Thank goodness, a map!
(READING) Bay E. Section seven. “Biscuits, flour and non- perishable baked goods.”
And look, ‘Bays A to Z’. That means there are twenty-five other bays. Each with thousands of different sections!
That’s an awful lot of biscuits. Bourbons... Ginger snaps...
(READING) Hardware, books and periodicals, furniture, electrical components... This place must be enormous!
It does seem to be extraordinarily well-stocked.
Well you’d think that they’d keep the place a bit cleaner. It’s hardly very inviting for shoppers. It’s all so gloomy.
I think you’ll find that the shopping experience has changed a little since your time, Mel. Whenever we are in your future... I presume that practically everything is done online.
Online? You mean orders placed by computer?
Precisely! The goods are stored in a central location like this and delivered direct to the shoppers’ homes as requested. By robotic drone most likely.
Really? Even things like books? And food?
Books, food, furniture, clothes... Pretty much everything.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 10
That’s all well and good, but what about the shops on the high street?
They’1ll become something of a novelty, I’m afraid. By the mid- 21°* century the high street at Pease Pottage will consist solely of one hundred and seventy three different coffee shops...
What? But that’s awful!
I agree. It’s almost impossible to get a cup of Earl Grey.
That’s not what I meant...

It’s progress, Mel. Like it or not, things change. If we took someone from this time back to the 1980s then they would be equally baffled by the way that you do things. You - more than most people - should appreciate how fast technology evolves...
I suppose so. I wonder what the world is like outside of this grubby old warehouse.
Well, let’s find out. (CROSSING FLOOR; MEL FOLLOWS) That looks like a shuttered window of some kind, wouldn’t you say?
Hmm. Maybe it should stay shuttered. Look at the warning sign. (READING) ‘Shield to be kept closed. Atmospheric seals to be checked regularly.’ — ‘Atmospheric’?
This keypad must raise the shutter...
HE PRESSES A SERIES OF BUTTONS THAT BEEP.
(TANNOY) EMERGENCY INSTRUCTION... EMERGENCY INSTRUCTION (STUTTERING) ACC—, ACC-... ACCEPTED.
WAS THAT?
Some sort of central computer control system, I presume.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL)
CLUNKS, CLICKS FROM SHUTTER.
Page 11
(TANNOY) Instruction accepted... Explosive bolts primed.
What?!?
Explosive bolts?! —Doctor, what have you done?
(TANNOY) Observation hatch release... Release... Imminent.
(FRANTICALLY PRESSING BUTTONS) I was trying to open the
shutters, that’s all!
Well that’s not what the computer thinks you’ve done. Stop it!
I’m trying, Mel, I’m trying!
(TANNOY) Emergency hatch purge cancelled... Cancelled.
Thank goodness for that!
Now. Let’s try that again, shall we...
BEEPS.
(TANNOY) Observation hatch... hatch... hatch. Observation hatch
seven... Open... Opening.
That computer really doesn’t sound very healthy!
HISS OF HYDRAULICS; SHUTTER OPENS.
(TANNOY) Observation hatch seven opening.
There you are, Mel. I must say, the view is quite
spectacular.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 12
We’re in orbit!
It makes sense. Place the warehouse in orbit and robotic drones can deliver to every continent on the planet below.
Where are they, then — these robotic drones?
Yes, we should be able to see them flying in and out of here like busy little bees. Perhaps it’s a bank holiday.
Still, at least we’ve got some light now. It’s a proper maze. These shelves really do look like they go on forever!
And there’s still that smell of decay...
Doctor, this is pretty dull. Why don’t we get on our way to Megrootii?
Just a little while longer, Mel, there’s a mystery here, I can feel it. (WALKING) Let’s head down this aisle for a bit. See if we can find a section for Jammy Dodgers.
(SIGH) Oh, alright then...
FOLLOWS. FADE.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 13
7. INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF WAREHOUSE
JEAN-E AND ANN-E ARE STOCKTAKING —ANN CHECKING ITEMS OFF ON AN
PAD.
JEAN-E: Shelf 4573B. Three hundred units.
ANN-E: (FX: PAD BEEP!) Check.
JEAN-E: Shelf 4573C. Two hundred and five units.
ANN-E: (FX: PAD BEEP!) Check.
JEAN-E: Shelf 4573D...
ALERT FROM ANN’S PAD — DIFFERENT TO CONFIRMATION BEEPS.
ANN-E: Hang on, Mum.
JEAN-E: What is it, Ann-E?
ANN-E:
I’m getting a system alert on the Pad. One of the observation windows. It looks like... there was nearly an emergency hatch purge. Should we tell Dad?
JEAN-E:

I wouldn’t bother your father with it. You know what he’s like when he gets his head down. He’s determined to get the stocktake of wafers, crackers and savoury snacks complete by the end of this shift. It’s probably just another computer error. (PAUSE) Or vermin...
ANN-E: Yes. I suppose it could be the vermin...
JEAN-E: Good girl. Now, where were we? Shelf 4573D...
ANN-E: (TO HERSELF) But why would the vermin be interfering with one of the observation windows?
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 14
8. INT. WAREHOUSE SHELVES
FX: DOCTOR AND MEL COME TO HALT.
That’s it. As far as the end of the aisle, you said, and here we are. — There’s nothing here, Doctor. Nothing but more
aisles, more biscuits and (SNIFFS) that revolting smell!
It does seem to be stronger than before. I wonder what could be causing it?
Mouldy digestives, probably. Can’t we just go back to the TARDIS? Please?
Just a minute, Mel. — Down that next aisle. At the far end, see?
See what? — Point with your umbrella.
There!! — Something glowing. Some sort of phosphorescence...
(DESPAIRING) Doctor...
I won’t be a moment. (DASHES OFF, THEN —)
METALLIC ‘SNAP’ OF A TRAP SHUTTING AROUND THE TIP OF THE DOCTOR'S UMBRELLA.
(DASHING FORWARD) Doctor!
It’s alright, just some sort of crude trap on the ground. Intersecting blades with a— (SUDDENLY NOTICING) Look what it’s done! It’s taken the end off my umbrella!
You should be thankful it was only that, and not your leg!
Yes, the edges are like razors...
Look. The aisle is full of them!
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 15
Fascinating...
Why so many?
More importantly, what is it they’re designed to catch?
Something rather bigger than a mouse.
There IS a mystery here, Mel. I knew it. Now, stay close. Step where I step.
Don’t you worry. I’m very attached to my extremities!
THEY CREEP FORWARD.
Urgh! That smell really IS appalling.
(STOPPING) Yes, and I rather think this might be the cause.
(COUGHING) What on Earth-?
Some sort of phosphorescent mould, I think.
It’s all over the packing crates. — Is it me, or is it glowing brighter the closer we get to it?
Yes, it seems to be reacting to our presence...
SUDDENLY, A LOUD SCRATCHING - CLAWS ON METAL — FROM UNDERNEATH THE FLOOR, CLOSE BY.
Are you sure it’s not the only thing reacting to our presence...?
Yes. You know, I think there’s something under the floor.
GETS LOUDER. TEARING METAL.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 16
Something trying to get out!
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 17
9. INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF WAREHOUSE
ALERT FROM ANN’S PAD.
ANN-E: Mum, there’s another sensor alert. In the under-floor cooling vents.
JEAN-E: What, in the same section?
ANN-E: Yes. I really do think we should tell Dad, you know.
APPROACH.
FRED-E: You really do think that you should tell Dad what?
JEAN-E: Oh! Fred-E, there you are. There’s a problem with the under- floor cooling systems.
FRED-E: (SIGHS) Bloomin’ vermin again!
JEAN-E: And one of the observation hatches has been triggered.
ANN-E: Hatch 367.
FRED-E: Right. Well, obviously my traps in that section are doing no good at all. (SIGHS) We’ve no choice. We’ll have to fumigate.
JEAN-E: (WORRIED) Again? So soon? You know there’s always a risk of contaminating the stock...
FRED-E:
We don’t have a lot of choice, Jean-E. If the blighters have got in there, then the stock’s all compromised anyway. (SIGHS AGAIN) Vermin!
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 18
10. INT. WAREHOUSE SHELVES
BANG! AS THE SCRATCHY THING UNDER FLOOR TRIES TO PUSH UP
RENT METAL.
Back... something coming to get us from under the floor. Forward... more of these rather nasty traps.
Which way? Doctor, we need to make a decision!
CACOPHONY OF CHALK-ON-BLACKBOARD SQUEALING AS THE FLOOR PANEL
SPLITS AND A LARGE, RAT-LIKE ALIEN CREATURE EMERGES. IT SHRIEK-SQUEALS.
(REVOLTED) Doctor, what is it?
A rodent species of some description.
What kind of rat grows to over a metre long?
The kind that tears through metal floors with worryingly sharp teeth and inordinately large claws.
2 x MORE RODENTS BURROWING UP THROUGH METAL.
There’s more of them! Doctor, they’re nearly out!
Forward would seem to be our only option.
But the traps! Staying here might be a quicker way to go.
You’re forgetting, Mel — (TAKING BAG OF MARBLES OUT OF POCKET,
THEM) — I found my lost marbles, remember?
I never forget a thing. But I don’t think your marbles will be much of a weapon against those creatures!
I’m not proposing to use them against those creatures. I’m proposing to use them thus:
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 19
HE THROWS THE MARBLES, SCATTERING THEM ACROSS THE FLOOR AHEAD...
ALL OF THE TRAPS AT ONCE. A CACOPHONY OF SNAPPING!
They’re triggering the traps. Brilliant!
A FINAL TEARING OF METAL; CLAWS SCRABBLE ONTO FLOOR. SHRIEK- SQUEALS.
Our furry friends are free. — Time to join the rat race, Mel.
Huh?
Run!
THE TWO OF THEM TEAR DOWN AISLE, PURSUED BY SQUEALING RATS.
(RUNNING) Do you think we can outrun them?
(RUNNING) We’re not going to try and outrun them. There are security doors at the end of each section, see. If we can close them behind us...
(TANNOY) Aisle two thousand... and seventy... four. Four. Two thousand and seventy four. Sealing.
AHEAD, HISS OF HYDRAULICS AS HEAVY METAL DOOR DESCENDS.
(RUNNING TO STOP) Oh, no! That stupid computer’s sealed off the section! (ALOUD TO THE TANNOY) You were supposed to close it
after we’d gone through, metal brains!
We’re trapped.
SUDDENLY, PURSUING RODENTS PAUSE. QUIZZICAL SQUEALS.
Those rat things, they’ve stopped! Why have they stopped?
(TANNOY) Aisle two thousand and seventy four. Sealed.
CREATURES RETREAT, SQUEALING.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 20
Now they’re retreating!
Yes, they must know what’s coming.
(TANNOY) Fumigation will commence in... in... in. Twenty seconds.
Fumigation. I don’t like the sound of that.
Quickly, Mel. Help me with this wall panel.
(TANNOY) Fifteen seconds.
THEY SCRABBLE TO OPEN A WALL PANEL WITH FINGERS.
Try and get your fingers under the edges...
It’s stuck.
Pull harder!
THEY PULL ASIDE METAL COVER. OPEN SPACE BEYOND.
Ah, yes! I thought so!
A conveyor belt!?
Part of the infrastructure! I knew they had to have some way of transporting goods between sections.
(TANNOY) Ten... ten seconds. Nine... Eight... Eight... Eight...
Quickly, Mel, through the hatch. Whilst that wretched machine is trying to remember how to count!
THE TWO OF THEM CLAMBER THROUGH THE HATCH. CLANG AS IT CLOSES
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 21
11. INT. CONVEYOR BELT [CONTINUOUS]
(TANNOY) Goods transit sys... sys... system. Goods transit system engaged. Auto... Auto packing initiated.
Well get on with it then!
BELT WHIRRS INTO LIFE.
Ah-hah! Success!
But where will it take us?
I’ve no idea, but it’s got to be better than [here. ]
WHOOSH! THE CONVEYOR BELT SPEEDS THEM AWAY.
& MEL: Waaagh!
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 22
12. INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF WAREHOUSE
ALERT BEEPS ON ANN’S PAD.
ANN-E: Dad. Now the auto packing system has come on-line.
FRED-E:
If the blighters have got into that... (PAUSE) Ann-E, do what you can to try and get that wretched computer to divert delivery to here. Then shut it down. Jean-E?
JEAN-E: Yes?
FRED-E: Go and get the tasers.
ANN-E: (PRESSING BUTTONS) I think I’ve managed to divert the conveyor system.
FRED-E: Good girl.
(TANNOY) Would the section manager please contact the Supervisor’s office?
FRED-E: (FRUSTRATED) Oh, not now. I’m busy!
(TANNOY) Repeat, section manager to contact the Supervisor's office... immediately.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 23
13. INT. CONVEYOR BELT
WHOOSH OF BELT.
(PITCHED UP) Doctor, I’m not sure how much longer I’m going to be able to hold on.
(PITCHED UP) Hang on, Mel. It’s got to start slowing down soon!
WHIRR OF MOTORS STARTING TO WIND DOWN.
There. I said so. We’re slowing.
That was like the worst roller coaster ride ever!
Oh, I don’t know. The Drashig’s Tail Ride on Cloraphon Beta is much worse! And I seem to recall that there’s a wooden roller coaster on Coney Island...
(TANNOY) Auto pack... packing. Auto packing initiated. Two items... Two items to be crated and sealed.
MACHINERY.
Oh no...
Doctor, behind you!
(GRABBED) Aaargh!
It’s some kind of mechanical arm! Get off, you great big-!
WHIRRS.
(GRABBED) Argh! Another one!
Let go of us, you wretched machines!
(TANNOY) Initiating crating process.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 24
AS DOCTOR AND MEL ARE SHUNTED BY MECHANICAL ARMS INTO CRATES.
(SHOVED INTO CRATE) They’re putting us into plastic crates!
Mind your head, Doctor! There’s a lid!
What’s that, M~— [el?]
STAMP OF A LID COMING DOWN, SEALING DOCTOR IN.
(TANNOY) Item success... successfully packed. Crating second
item.
Get off!
LID SLAMS SHUT.
(TANNOY) Second item... item.. item... packed. Crating complete.
BEAT.
(MUFFLED, THROUGH CRATE) Doctor, what’s happening?
(MUFFLED) The system is treating us like any other goods shipment. We’re being packaged and delivered to the correct shelf in the warehouse. We should be perfectly safe.
(TANNOY) Items... items to be... to be...
(MUFFLED) Or not to be?
(TANNOY) Items designated: hardware. To be... vacuum sealed.
(MUFFLED) Vacuum sealed?
(MUFFLED) The stupid computer doesn’t realise we’re organic!
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 25
HISS OF AIR BEING EXTRACTED.
(BANGING ON INSIDE OF CRATE) Doctor!!!
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 26
14. INT. FRED-E’S OFFICE
CONNECTING — LIKE A MODERN PHONE RINGING.
(PHONE DISTORT) Supervisor’s office.
FRED-E: You asked me to call, sir.
(D) Ah. Fred-E, my boy. I see that you’ve had to fumigate again.
FRED-E: Yes, sir. We had a vermin problem...
(D) That’s the third time this month.
FRED-E: Yes, well the traps don’t seem to be [working]
(D) Excuses? You know how I hate excuses.
FRED-E: Yes, sir. If I could just...
(D) I do hope that we don’t have a problem here, Fred-E. The vermin need to be controlled. You assured me that you could cope with it.
FRED-E: Yés,; (sir. I'm Sorry; “Sir.
(D) I would hate to have to replace you. Although, it’d be easily done...
FRED-E: I assure you that won’t be necessary.
(D) Good lad. Now, I have reason to believe that there might intruders in the Warehouse.
FRED-E: Intruders? (REALISING) The observation hatch, of course!
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 27
(D) I beg your pardon?
FRED-E: I have a feeling that we might have just caught your intruders, Supervisor.
D) How very industrious of you, my boy. (SUDDENLY HARD
So find out who they are, find out how they got here, and report back to me.
FRED-E: At once, sir.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 28
15. INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF WAREHOUSE
WHIRR OF CONVEYOR BELT AS CRATES ARE DELIVERED.
(TANNOY) Delivering two.. two items. Two items vacuum-sealed.
ANN-E: Here they come.
JEAN-E: Vermin in the system, got to be. You know what you’ve got to do? I'll lift the lids, you stand ready with that taser.
ANN-E: Mind you don’t get bitten.
COMES TO A HALT. BANGING FROM INSIDE CRATES.
(TANNOY) Delivery. Delivery complete.
(MUFFLED, INSIDE CRATE) Help! Help!!! Doctor, I can’t breathe!
(MUFFLED, INSIDE CRATE) Stay calm, Mel...!
ANN-E: (ASTONISHED) That’s not vermin!
JEAN-E: What the...?!
ANN-E: Lift the lid, Mum!
AS LID RELEASED, SHOVED ASIDE.
(FALLS OUT, GASPING) Thank you...
JEAN-E: Who the blinking [heck-?]
(BREATHLESS) Introductions later, my friend’s suffocating.
ANN-E: Mum, the other crate!
LID OPENED.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 29
GASPING
Are you alright, Mel?
Well — now I know what a parcel in the post feels like.
Not-so-special delivery...
HISS OF A DOOR AS FRED-E ENTERS.
JEAN-E: Look, who are you two? How did you get in here?
Are you in charge here?
FRED-E: (APPROACHING) No. I am.
ANN-E: Dad! There you are!
Very pleased to meet you. I’m the Doctor —
. and I’m Melanie.
JEAN-E: ‘Melan-E’ ?
Mel for short. We’re travellers.
FRED-E: Fred-E. This is my wife, Jean-E, and my daughter, Ann-E.
ANN-E: Are you not from the surface?
You mean, the planet below?
We arrived here by mistake. All of you, listen... you’ve got bigger things to worry about than us. Bigger and furrier.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 30
JEAN-E: You mean the vermin.
Yes. Quite an infestation. What are they?
FRED-E: A menace, that’s what they are.
So it was you set all those traps?
FRED-E: Clear one nest, another one springs up. They’re playing havoc with the stocktake.
Surely there can’t only be three of you looking after a place this huge?
ANN-E: No, of course not. We just look after Bay E. There’s a family unit for each section.
Ah! — So there are twenty-six families, all up here in orbit.
ANN-E: That’s right. We do maintenance, security... and the stocktake, of course. (SIGHS) Much of it manually, these days.
FRED-E: We’ve no choice. Not since the computer system went down.
Yes. Your computer does seem to be behaving somewhat erratically!
That’s an understatement. Downright dangerous if you ask me!
Yes, well — perhaps you should do something about fixing it, Mel.
Me?
You’re the computer expert.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL)
Yes, but...
Then you’re just what these people need!
FRED-E:
Page 31
Well... I’d have to check with the Supervisor...
JEAN-E: It can’t do any harm, Fred-E.
ANN-E: Please, Dad... If there’s any chance that
FRED-E: Alright, alright. I’11 ask.

DOCTOR: ANN-F: Hold on. Doctor — did we come this way earlier...?
DOCTOR: No, I don’t believe we did.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: So who made those footprints, on the path ahead?
DOCTOR: Good question, Ann-F. Here’s another: who made the path? —A path leading up to a particular long, low structure...
DOCTOR: ANN-F: See? There ARE still people alive here! (DASHING OFF) Come on!
DOCTOR: (CALLING AFTER) Ann, slow down!
CROSSFADE TO: THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 74
SWING: DOORS PUSHED OPEN, AS BEFORE.
SWING: ANN-F: (DISAPPOINTED) There’s no one here.
DOCTOR: (WALKING UP BEHIND) Good. That means that we have time to work out how we’re going to introduce ourselves properly.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: What was this place, do you suppose?
DOCTOR: Once? The loading bay of a superstore, perhaps. Judging by the way that altar has been garlanded with flowers, now it’s become some kind of temple. Only instead of an idol on the altar...
DOCTOR: ANN-F: . it’s a computer terminal.
DOCTOR: THEY RUSH FORWARD TO ALTAR.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: Doctor — it’s exactly the same as the terminals in the Warehouse. That can’t be a coincidence!
DOCTOR: TAPS AT KEYBOARD.
TERMINAL: (FLICKERY, FAINT) Please... place your order.
TERMINAL: ANN-F: It’s still working!
DOCTOR: Solar cells keep the terminal going. But with the communications gone, it can’t connect to the Warehouse mainframe. (TURNING) I might have something back in the TARDIS to... (SEES SOMETHING) Oh.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Turn around.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: (TURNING) What is it?
DOCTOR: THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 75
DOCTOR: Above the door. The mural.
DOCTOR: ANN-F : That’s the Warehouse!
DOCTOR: And hanging in space above the Warehouse, is...?
DOCTOR: ANN-F : No! But that’s...!
DOCTOR: Not quite Michelangelo, perhaps, but I think the likenesses are rather good, don’t you? Fred, Jean... and yourself, Ann. All giant size.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: But if this place is a temple of some kind...
DOCTOR: Then you and your clone family are being revered as deities.
DOCTOR: THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 76
MEL: Three hundred and fifty years, that’s impossible!
MEL: FRED-G: Not really. We clones come with a five-hundred-year guarantee.
MEL: And all you’ve done in all that time is stocktake?!
MEL: ANN-G: Well, yes. It’s what we were designed to do.
MEL: You said. Don’t you ever get bored, you Gs? Don’t you wish that you had a life beyond this?
MEL: JEAN-G: Doing what?
MEL: I don’t know. Reading books? Watching films? Interacting with other family units?
MEL: ANN-G: But we’re not programmed for that.
MEL: JEAN-G: You feel sorry for us, because you think we have desires like yours. But we don’t, and that’s that.
MEL: It’s horrible. Cruel and horrible.
MEL: ANN-G: Do you think asking that computer to run a system diagnostic is horrible? Or to ask it open a door, or turn on a light?
MEL: But that’s completely different!
MEL: ANN-G: Isn’t it just a matter of perspective? It’s a machine designed to do a job of work.
MEL: FRED-G: Exactly. We clones — we’re just organic machines, designed for one purpose.
MEL: THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 77
COMPUTER: (TANNOY) Movement detected. Section nine. Aisle eight thousand and thirty three. Damage to coolant pipes.
COMPUTER: FRED-G:
COMPUTER: Blasted vermin again! Come on, Jean. (TO MEL) Look, Melan-E: if you really want to help us, you just carry on with those repairs.
MEL: But —
FRED: & JEAN EXIT. DOOR OPENS AND CLOSES.
FRED: ANN-G: You really don’t have to worry about us, Mel. We’re perfectly happy — Mum, Dad and me.
MEL: But only because you’re programmed not to notice that you’re un-happy. (BEAT) Well — if fixing this computer will help, then that’s what I’m going to do. Come on, let’s see if we can get some this wiring back into some kind of order...
MEL: THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 78
DOCTOR: Over here, Ann-F — take a look at this.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: (WALKING OVER) What is it?
DOCTOR: Writing on the pillars either side of the mural.
DOCTOR: ANN-F:
DOCTOR: (READING) “Deliver unto us bread and meat... Deliver unto us warm clothing... Deliver unto us weapons for the hunt...” What is it, a prayer of some kind?
DOCTOR: Not a prayer. A list.
DOCTOR: ANN-F : A list?
DOCTOR: A shopping list. Every line on these pillars is an order, placed with the Gods — placed with you, Fred and Jean!
DOCTOR: ANN-F: Stop it Doctor! We’re not Gods!
DOCTOR: To the people who built this temple you are. Hanging in the skies, with a warehouseful of unimaginable bounty...
DOCTOR: ANN-F: You mean — they worship us?
DOCTOR: (QUIETLY, TO HIMSELF) A cargo cult.
DOCTOR: ANN-F : A what?
DOCTOR: It’s a cargo cult. I saw something similar on the planet Earth, in the early twentieth century. The inhabitants of the Melanesian islands came to believe that ritualistic acts would bring them material wealth.
DOCTOR: ANN-F : I don’t understand.
DOCTOR: THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 79
DOCTOR: The Melanesian islanders were first-hand witnesses to a war fought by two great technological nations. When they saw cargo planes delivering food and equipment to the troops, they thought the gods were delivering wealth from the sky — and began worshipping them in the hope that they, too, would be blessed with supplies.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: And you think that’s what has happened here?
DOCTOR: It would make sense. Everything that this society needs to repair itself has been hanging in plain sight for hundreds of years. But all their attempts to communicate have failed.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: So if Mel repairs the computer...
DOCTOR: Then I guess that this terminal, and hundreds of others like it, will start working again, and the drones will start delivering.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: So let’s get back to the Warehouse, and help Mel!
DOCTOR: It’s not as simple as that. From the look of this place, hundreds of years have gone by. The survivors started out civilised, but in the intervening centuries — well, who knows how low they might have s—[unk] (TRAILING OFF) Ah.
SIMULTANEOUSLY: 4 x ACOLYTES APPROACHING FROM OUTSIDE, HAULING
LYDEK: INTO THE TEMPLE. WE CANT YET HEAR CLEARLY WHAT THEY’RE CHANTING, BUT IT GOES LIKE THIS:
LYDEK: 4 X ACOLYTES: (CHANTING) Danger, vehicle reversing. Danger, vehicle reversing. [ETC]
LYDEK: ANN-F: (EXCITED) Survivors!
DOCTOR: Approaching the Temple. Quick, behind the pillars!
DOCTOR: ANN-F : Shouldn’t we introduce ourselves?
DOCTOR: THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 80
DOCTOR: (IMPATIENT) And what will you tell them, Ann-F? ‘Hello, I’m one of the Gods you’ve been worshipping. Sorry we’ve been ignoring you all these centuries, but we thought we’d just drop by to see how you’re doing?’
DOCTOR: ANN-F: Yes, you might have a point.
DOCTOR: Besides, look at where we are. In my experience - which is painfully extensive - the faithful tend to get a bit touchy when you intrude upon their holy of holies without permission. Now ssh!
SWING: DOORS CRASH OPEN. ACOLYTES GRUNT WITH EFFORT AS THEY PULL
LYDEK: INTO THE TEMPLE ON TOP OF A CAR CHASSIS. NOW WE HEAR
THEIR CHANT CLEARLY: 4 X ACOLYTES: (CHANTING) Danger, vehicle reversing. Danger, vehicle reversing. [ETC]
DOORS: SWING SHUT.
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) Fascinating.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: (SOTTO) What is it they’re bringing that woman in on?
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) The remains of a goods vehicle of some kind. Four acolytes pulling a four by four.
CHANTING: STOPS AS LYDEK IS SET DOWN.
LYDEK: Loyal Service Assistants, we are gathered once again to beg the Gods for Delivery! To fill the sky with the soft drone of angels!
LYDEK: THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 81
COMPUTERY: NOISES.
MEL: (CURSING) Oh, rats!
MEL: ANN-G: (ALARMED) Vermin? Here!
MEL: No, Ann-G — that’s not what I meant. Sorry. Not the best choice of curse, in the circumstances.
MEL: ANN-G: Well, what’s wrong?
MEL: This logic board, that’s what’s wrong.
MEL: ANN-G: It’s broken?
MEL: Completely. Most of the other damage can be repaired, but there’s nothing I can do with this. It’s going to have to be completely replaced.
MEL: ANN-G: There must be a spare, somewhere in the Warehouse.
MEL: Oh, I’m sure there is.
MEL: ANN-G: Well then, what’s the problem?
MEL: All the computer spares... They’re in Bay F.
MEL: THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 82
ACOLYTE: #1: Stop the ceremony!
LYDEK: You forget yourself, Acolyte!
ACOLYTE: #1: High Priestess. There has been a blasphemy!
LYDEK: Explain!
ACOLYTE: #1: The terminal has been disturbed. Someone has tried to send a request...
LYDEK: (CROSSING TO THE ACOLYTE; SHOCKED) Another blasphemy! Will
LYDEK: these heresies never cease? — When?
KEYBOARD: CLATTER.
TERMINAL: Please... place your order.
ACOLYTE: #1: Within the last few minutes.
LYDEK: Then the blasphemers could still be somewhere inside the temple. Seal the exits! Spread out, Service Assistants, and find them!
LYDEK: 4 x ACOLYTES SPREAD OUT — SEARCHING, TURNING OVER BOXES ETC. CROSS TO DOCTOR AND ANN, HIDING BEHIND PILLAR.
LYDEK: ANN-F: (SOTTO) Doctor, they’1l find us any second.
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) I know. Stay here, Ann-F.
DOCTOR: ANN-F: (WH) What are you going to do?
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) Talk to them. Try to explain.
DOCTOR: THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 83
DOCTOR: ANN-F: (SOTTO) They’ve got spears!
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) Stay here. (STEPS OUT FROM HIDING, COUGHS LOUDLY) Good
DOCTOR: afternoon.
ACOLYTE: #1: Priestess! A blasphemer!
LYDEK: Seize him!
ACOLYTES: RUSH FORWARD TO GRAB DOCTOR.
DOCTOR: Alright, alright. (GRABBED) There’s no need to be so heavy- handed.
LYDEK: (APPROACHING) I do not know you. Who are you?
DOCTOR: A traveller. My name’s the Doctor. I’m here to help.
LYDEK: Did you defile the terminal?
DOCTOR: I was seeing if I could establish a link with the Warehouse.
LYDEK: (SHOCKED) So you freely admit your guilt!
DOCTOR: If you would just let me explain...
LYDEK: What is there to explain? You are a stranger who has defiled our temple. Service Assistants — raise your spears! And put this blasphemer to death!
DOCTOR: What-? No!
DOCTOR: END OF PART TWO
DOCTOR: THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 84

elements.text: PART THREE
Did you defile the terminal?
I was seeing if I could establish a link with the Warehouse.
(SHOCKED) So you freely admit your guilt!
If you would just let me explain...
What is there to explain? You are a stranger who has defiled our temple. Service Assistants — raise your spears! And put this blasphemer to death!
What—? No!
47. INT. TEMPLE
Let this stranger’s death be pleasing to the Gods, and deliver wealth to their devoted [servants. ]
ANN-F: (STEPPING OUT FROM BEHIND PILLAR) Stop! Let him go!
4 x ACOLYTES:
GASPS OF AWE
At last.. The Gods walk amongst us!
Now that’s really put the cat among the pigeons...
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 85
48. INT. COMPUTER ROOM
SOUNDS IN B/G.
So, Fred-G. What do you reckon?
FRED-G: A raid? On Bay F? I don’t know...
JEAN-G: Is it really necessary?
If you want me to repair that computer it is. (SIGHS) Why the computer spares weren’t put in the same section as the computer itself, I’1ll never know.
ANN-G: I doubt anyone ever considered the possibility of family units not co-operating.
I suppose it is a bit like arguing with yourself...
JEAN-G: But how are we going to get in there?
We need a distraction of some kind. Something to keep the Fs occupied long enough for us to sneak in and get hold of the logic board I need.
ANN-G: What kind of distraction?
I don’t know! I was rather hoping you’d be able to suggest something.
FRED-G: The fumigation system. (BEAT) We should be able to override the safety cut-out and channel the gas into their section.
I wouldn’t want anyone to get hurt.
FRED-G:
They won’t. The Fs have got gas masks. Besides, now you’ve got some of the computer working, I should be able to get it to reduce the concentration of the gas to a less harmful level.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 86
JEAN-G: You won’t have long to get in and out though. He’s a smart one, Fred-F — it won’t take him long to work out what you’re up to.
Right. How will I know which aisle to look for?
ANN-G: I can show you.
JEAN-G: No, Ann.
ANN-G: I want to help! You know I’m good with stock location.
JEAN-G: (FIRM) I said no! If anyone’s going, it’s going to be me. It’s about time we all pulled together and did something.
Well said, Jean-G. Right, then. Let’s get cracking!
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 87
49. INT. TEMPLE
#1: She has come...
#2: Saint Ann. As it was foretold.
#1: The delivery will begin...
#2: The sky shall be filled with angels...
I thought I told you to stay hidden!
ANN-F: The way that things were going, I didn’t think that I had any other choice.
I had hoped that I could introduce you in a slightly less dramatic way!
ANN-F: So, what do you think we should do now?
Well, given that you now seem to be revered... let’s see if we can use that to our advantage, shall we? (TO LYDEK) Excuse me — High Priestess?
ACOLYTES GO SILENT.
(HESITANT) Are — are you truly from the Warehouse?
We are.
And is it true that the shelves are lined with riches?
Well, it’s not short of biscuits, but they may not do your teeth any favours. — What’s your name?
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 88
I am Lydek. High Priestess of the Terminal.
And you recognise this girl?
Of course. Everyone knows Saint Ann, youngest of the benefactors. Have you finally come to deliver us the wealth we need?
ANN-F: EY...
A few more questions first, about the past. About the history of your, er, tribe?
Saint Ann — is this man a prophet? Does he speak with your authority? If not, I can easily have him put to death.
ANN-F: No, no! It’s fine. He has my authority. Tell him what he wants to know.
Very well. (TO ACOLYTES) Service assistants! Loyalty card holders!
#1 & #2: Yes, High Priestess?
Go outside the Temple and guard the doors. Admit no-one. I must speak to the Gods alone.
#1 & #2: Yes, High Priestess!
EXIT. DOORS SWING SHUT. OVER THIS:
ANN-F: (SOTTO) You know, I could get used to being treated as a God!
(SOTTO) Well, don’t. It rarely ends well.
Saint Ann, and her prophet — follow me.
FOLLOW A FEW STEPS ACROSS THE TEMPLE.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 89
Where are you taking us?
These hangings conceal a secret known to only a few.
CURTAIN BEING PULLED ASIDE.
ANN-F: A blastproof door!
No, not blastproof. Look at the seals at the edges. It’s an anti-contamination door. There must be some kind of bunker beneath us.
It is the entrance to the underworld.
ANN-F : The what?
CLUNKS AND CLANGS AS BOLTS AND CATCHES ARE UNDONE. DOOR SWINGS OPEN.
To the catacombs. Follow me - and I will show you what you want to know.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 90
50. INT. OUTSIDE BAY F
THEY TALK IN HUSHED TONES
Right. There’s the door to Bay F. Is everyone ready?
ANN-G: / FRED-G: / JEAN-G: (MURMUR ASSENT) Yes, Ready.
As soon as Fred starts the fumigation, you open the door, Ann...
JEAN-G: And we run in.
As fast as we can. Are you sure you know which aisle we're heading for, Jean-G?
JEAN-G: Positive.
(DEEP BREATH) Right, gas-masks on.
MEL AND JEAN PULL ON GAS MASKS, WHICH MUFFLES THEIR VOICES SLIGHTLY FROM NOW UNTIL THEY ARE REMOVED.
(MASK) Ready when you are, Fred.
PRESSES AT A KEYBOARD.
(TANNOY) Fumigation systems online. Fumigating Bay F.
HISS OF GAS [BEHIND DOOR].
FRED-G: Now, Ann!
KEYPAD. HISS OF HYDRAULICS.
(TANNOY) Fire door to Bay F opening.
ANN-G: Go!
(MASK) Come on, Jean — run!
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 91
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 92
51. INT. BAY F [CONTINUOUS]
HISS OF GAS. MEL AND JEAN RUN TO HALT.
(MASK) Which way?
JEAN-G: (MASK) Down here!
(MASK) Are you sure? I can’t see a thing through this gas!
JEAN-G: (MASK) Yes! Hurry!
AS THEY RUN.
JEAN-G: (MASK) We take this aisle all the way to the end, then turn left.
(MASK) Jean, wait. (THEY STOP) There’s something moving, down the aisle ahead!
FRED-F: (OFF, COUGHING AND SPLUTTERING) Jean? Is that you?
JEAN-G: (MASK - SOTTO) It’s Fred-F. What are we going to do?
(MASK - SOTTO) You’1ll have to bluff it.
JEAN-G: (MASK - SOTTO) What?
(MASK — SOTTO) You’re a clone, aren’t you? Pretend that you’re his Jean!
CLOSE TO FRED-F.
FRED-F: (COUGHING) Who’s that?
JEAN-G: (APPROACHING, MASK) It’s me, Fred. Only me.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 93
FRED-F:
(COUGHING) Jean? (COUGHS) Blasted computer must have malfunctioned... Hey, where’d you get your mask from? I thought you said the filters needed changing.
(MASK) I, er..
FRED-F: (REALISATION) Wait a minute..! You’re not Jean-F, you’re —
(OFF, MASK) Run for it, Jean!
RUNS, FOLLOWED BY MEL. FRED-F:
That Melan-E woman! — This is your doing, isn’t it?! Come back here! (MORE COUGHING)
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 94
52. INT. BUNKER — PASSAGE
ECHOING AS DOCTOR AND ANN-F FOLLOW LYDEK.
ANN-F: (ASIDE) Those stairs seemed to go on forever. How deep do you think we are?
(ASIDE) Hard to say. It looks to me like these tunnels used to be part of a transit system of some kind.
ANN-F: (ASIDE) Converted into a shelter?
(ASIDE) Yes, and sealed off from the infection outside.
ANN-F: (ASIDE) So they were stuck down here, in the dark...
(ASIDE) Until the infection burned itself out, perhaps.
ANN-F: (ASIDE) But these tunnels can only have sheltered a few hundred survivors. What about everyone else?
(ASIDE) I don’t know. (STOPPING; ALOUD) Lydek, are there other tunnels like these? Other temples?
The oracle will tell you everything you need to know.
Oracle?
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 95
53. INT. BAY F SHELVES
MEL AND JEAN COME TO A HALT, BREATHING HEAVILY.
(MASK) It’s alright, Fred-F’s not following. I think we lost him.
JEAN-G: (MASK) I think we lost us too.
(MASK) Jean, you said that you knew your way around these shelves!
JEAN-G: (MASK) I just need to re-orientate myself. Give me a moment.
(MASK) Do you think it’s safe to take these masks off?
JEAN-G: (MASK) Yes. Even if some of the gas drifted this far, it should have dispersed by now.
THEY REMOVE GAS MASKS.
Oh, that’s miles [better] —
RAT SCRATCHING FROM UNDER FLOOR, CONTINUING
JEAN-G: Ssh! Do you hear that?
Yes, I think the fumigation must have stirred things with our verminous friends. Do you know where we are now?
JEAN-G: Yes... yes. Section 478. We need to go this way.
I hope you’re right. Come on!
THEY RACE OFF.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 96
54. INT. ORACLE ROOM
A SMALL, CONTAINED CHAMBER. HATCH CLANGS OPEN. LYDEK LEADS
& ANN-F IN.
Behold, the Oracle!
ANN-F: (SLIGHTLY LET DOWN) There’s no-one here.
(CROSSING FLOOR QUICKLY, WITH ANN-F) Of course! An experiential memory bank.
ANN-F : A what?

This society has, or rather had, a clone-based workforce system, Ann; you, Fred and Jean are the living proof. The cloning process creates fully formed adults, but without the lifetime of knowledge needed to be able to function correctly.
ANN-F: And that’s what this machine does? Implants knowledge?

. directly into the memory centres of the clone brain, yes. This one, I presume, has been loaded with the knowledge needed to programme a clone workforce to rebuild this civilisation. — Am I right, Lydek?
Your words are strange, but I think I understand your meaning. The Oracle was built by our ancestors. It contains the history of our people.
I’m right, then. May I-?
PRESSES A FEW BUTTONS. VERY FAINT ‘TICKING OVER’.
ANN-F: Well?
It’s barely working. Like the Terminal in the temple, the solar cells have all but disintegrated.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 97
We try to keep the wisdom of the Oracle alive, passing it down from High Priestess to High Priestess. But every generation, the voice of the Oracle becomes harder to hear...
I’m amazed that the telepathic generators have run as long as they have...
But there is another way to access its voice. A secret shown to me by my mother, and her mother before her.
ANN-F : How?
With prayer.
Ah.
And a special powder.
What ‘powder’?
I shall show you.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 98
55. INT. BAY F SHELVES
JEAN-G & MEL SEARCHING SHELVES.
JEAN-G: Mel. Up there. Top shelf, three along. Is that it?
The logic board. At last! We’re lucky. It looks like there’s only one left in stock!
JEAN-G: I’1l climb up and get it, then we can get out of here. (STEPS
METAL LADDER)
Hurry! Now that the gas has cleared, I’m worried that getting out of here isn’t going to be as easy as getting in...
JEAN-G: (UP LADDER) Got it!
SCRATCHING AGAIN.
Come on. Those rat-things seem more determined than ever.
JEAN-G: (UP LADDER) Just changing the stock level card to zero.
(INCREDULOUS) Jean! Leave it!
JEAN-G: I can’t. It goes against my programming. It’1ll only take a [moment...]
RENDING AS THE ‘RATS’ TEAR THROUGH FLOOR. SHRIEK-SQUEALING
They’re coming through! Dozens of them! Jean — help!
JEAN-G: Climb the ladder, Mel!
(STARTS TO CLIMB, BUT IS ATTACKED) Aaaah! One’s got my leg! Jean!
JEAN-G: (BESIDE) I — I don’t...
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 99
That fire extinguisher! Quickly!
TAKES A COUPLE OF STEPS DOWN THE LADDER.
JEAN-G: (PULLING EXTINGUISHER OFF WALL — EFFORT) Got it! Here.
I can’t take it. If I loosen my grip, I’11l be pulled down. Spray it at them!
JEAN-G: (WRESTLING WITH PIN) The pin’s stiff!
Hurry, Jean..! They’re coming along the shelves now!
JEAN-G: (STRIKES PIN) Got it!
‘WHOOSH’ OF CO2. ‘RATS’ RUN OFF, SQUEALING.
JEAN-G: (DROPS FIRE EXTINGUISHER, CLIMBS DOWN THE LADDER) Mel? Are you alright? Did they bite you?
No. No, I’m fine. There’s not a scratch on me. — It’s almost as if...
JEAN-G:; What?
As if they didn’t want to hurt me. What did you do with that logic board?
JEAN-G: I put down on the shelf when... (REALISATION) It’s gone!
That’s why they attacked me! To distract us.
JEAN-G: The vermin? But what would they want with a computer component?
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 100
Why did they attack the computer in the first place? (THEY BOTH CLIMB THE REMAINING FEW RUNGS DOWN THE LADDER TO THE FLOOR) I’ve a feeling there’s far more to these creatures than meets the [eye.]
FRED-F: (DISTANT) Where are they?
JEAN-G: Ssh, Mel!
JEAN-F: (DISTANT) I think that I heard something down here...
(SOTTO) We’d better get out of here.
JEAN-G: (SOTTO) Not that way! Bay G is the other direction.
(SOTTO) We’re not going back to Bay G. We’re going into the service ducts after those rats!
JEAN-G: (SOTTO) You want to follow the vermin?
(SOTTO) There’s not much point in going back if we don’t have that component. And besides, I want to find out a bit more about our rodent friends.
CLANG, EFFORT AS MEL SHIFTS RENT FLOOR PANEL.
FRED-F: (DISTANT) I can hear voices. They’re this way!
(CLIMBING THROUGH HOLE IN FLOOR) Quickly, Jean! With luck they’1l think we’re heading back the other way, and won’t think of looking down here.
JEAN-G: You’re right, they won’t. Who in their right mind would climb into ducts full of deadly vermin?
I’m not so sure about ‘deadly’. Come on, follow me.
AS THEY SCRAMBLE INTO DUCT BELOW.
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 101
56. INT. ORACLE ROOM
ANN-F: (SOTTO) Look at her. Incense and candles and bowls of powder. All to access a computer?
(SOTTO) Fascinating, isn’t it? Mysticism and technology all jumbled up.
ANN-F: (SOTTO) But how can it possibly work?

(SOTTO) I once witnessed something similar, among a lost tribe of the Amazon. I’m guessing that the chemicals in the smoke open up the neural pathways of whoever breathes it, allowing the weak telepathic signal being generated by the computer to connect.
(ALOUD) It is ready. We can begin.
ANN-F: (SOTTO) Good luck, Doctor.
Breathe in the smoke, prophet. Let it open your mind.
BREATHES IN DEEPLY. COUGHS AND SPLUTTERS.
ANN-F: Maybe breathe more shallowly?
Thank you for your valuable advice. (INHALES)
Yes, yes! Let the vapours seep into you. (DOCTOR’S POV — HER
BECOMING DISTANT AND ECHOEY) Oracle of the people, reveal the past to this prophet. Reveal to him your secrets...
THE WAREHOUSE by Mike Tucker (FINAL) Page 102
